prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model, showing the impact of different levels of shielding, α, on infectious cases and the final state of the system. The model assumes a transmission rate (β) of 0.25 and a recovery rate (γ) of 0.1. It is important to consider interactions with patients in hospital settings when implementing healthcare worker scenarios. Baseline epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risk, and population structure details can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2, as well as in the code available on GitHub at https://github.com/WeitzGroup/covid_shield_immunity. The study uses these parameters to seed an outbreak and implement a shielding strategy once total prevalence reaches 0.1%. Different outbreak scenarios with varying transmission rates are examined, with R0 values of 1 and 2.33 in low and high transmission scenarios, respectively. Early estimates from Wuhan suggest an R0 between 2.1 and 4.5 within a 95% confidence interval.30),  putting  our high-transmission  scenario  on  the  conservative  end  of  estimated ranges. However,  the   of  the  high-transmission  scenario  we examine  here  is  consistent  with  the  range  of  2.0–2.6  considered in ref. 5, and with the median of  (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in Japan that account  for  undocumented  transmission28. Moreover,  given  that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in  Japan  from  24  January  to  3  February  after  travel  restrictions
post_context:
2:38 and other measures were implemented.The results in Figure 3 demonstrate the impact of different shielding interventions compared to baseline outbreak scenarios. Just like in the basic SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of an epidemic in various ways, decreasing overall impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 individuals in a high-transmission setting, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared to 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. For a population of the same size in a low-transmission scenario, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite a lower percentage of individuals in the 60 years and older age range, the majority of deaths occur in this group, consistent with other COVID-19 models and outbreaks in Italy and Japan.

Our simulations focus on the effects of shielding alone, while ongoing restrictions like social distancing and shelter-in-place orders will further reduce interaction rates. The success of shielding relies on the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability (αRshields), taking into account the identification and interaction rate among recovered individuals. The overall impact of shielding on a population depends on various factors, such as demographic distribution, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may see greater benefits from shielding. Although there are fewer recovered individuals between the ages of 20 and 60, they still contribute to the effectiveness of shielding efforts.

Even though  there  are  fewer  recovered  individuals  between  the  ages  of 20 and 60 to draw f

original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Email: chenh@big.ac.cn 
Date: February 29, 2020
Subject: COVID-19 Dynamics Study

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the last two months. This disease has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

In this study, we introduce a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. We explicitly consider the intervention effects of control measures, making our model more suitable for this analysis than other existing epidemic models.

Our results, based on daily confirmed infection data, show the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hangzhou, Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), China (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of China. We observed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hangzhou, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be beneficial in predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and numerous countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting actual dynamics, and the impact of quarantine measures on controlling the spread. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, utilizing data from China to forecast the epidemic's progression. The model can also offer valuable insights for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over the past two months. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the real dynamics versus daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention effects.

Methods: A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and incorporate the effects of implemented control measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model was used to analyze daily confirmed infection data in Wuhan, Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Jiangxi), and four major cities in China. The analysis revealed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangxi excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jiangxi (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Jiangxi is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Jiangxi, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Jiangxi).The estimates provided in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Jiangxi until late March. This model can also be valuable in predicting the course of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and across more than 30 countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting of confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures like quarantine. The SUQC model developed in this study aims to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to China's daily data to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic. This model can also provide valuable insights for other countries at risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. contents: location: the city of shanghai.; time: feb 14
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1B, there is a noticeable disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in The city of Shanghai. The local medical agency in The city of Shanghai began employing clinical diagnosis as a supplementary criterion for diagnosis post Feb 14, resulting in a significant rise in confirmed infections. Despite this, there still remains a portion of total infected individuals who are not identified even with clinical diagnosis. By utilizing inferred parameters, long-term predictions of total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in The city of Shanghai are plotted in Figure 1A. The model predicts that the end time (when the confirmed infections stop increasing) will be 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Similar analyses can be conducted using The city of Shanghai's stage I data, which can help predict epidemic trends without stringent quarantine measures. By using the first 10 daily data points from January 20 to infer parameters and the remaining data to test the model's performance, it is evident that the predicted numbers of confirmed and infected individuals (C(t) and I(t)) sharply rise beyond observed numbers after January 21, as shown in Figure 1C. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. The reproductive number in Chengdu decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III, indicating that the epidemic in China is relatively under control. Individuals who are not in quarantine are the main source of new infections. Based on data from stage II, it is estimated that there are still 3,509 unquarantined individuals in Chengdu as of Feb 12 (Fig.1A), and person-to-person transmission is predicted to continue until mid May 2020. By fitting the model with recent data from stages II and III, predictions are made about the future dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The epidemic in Chengdu and Hubei (excluding Chengdu) is expected to end around late March, while the end time for the four first-tier cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen) is predicted to be before early March. It is anticipated that the end time with zero un-quarantined infections will be earlier than that with zero new confirmed infections.

pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is denoted by δ. To model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the control by artificial factors, a set of ODE equations (Eq.1) is established. In the model, infected individuals either go directly to being confirmed (C), or indirectly through quarantine (Q). By simplifying the model and removing the direct way, we arrive at Eq. 2. Parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T=1/g1) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w=1/(g2 - (1 - g2))) can be defined based on the SUQC model. The reproductive number of the infection is R=α/g1. When it comes to parameter inference, the number of cumulative confirmed infections (C(t)) is typically the only variable with daily observed data for model fitting and parameter estimation. The initial values of susceptible individuals (S(0)) is generally assumed to be equal to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections (C(0)) is obtained from official reports.Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China during February 20 and Feb 28. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: .The number of confirmed infections during this time period may provide a more accurate representation of the true nature of COVID-19, as early confirmed numbers are affected by various factors such as small fluctuations and strict quarantine measures. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 depending on the method used. Thankfully, in our model, the exact value of α is not crucial as the overall infection ability, measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive to parameter optimization. By balancing the bias of α with other parameters like g1, we can accurately estimate the values of g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ by fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model. The loss function is then optimized using the MATLAB function fmincon to determine the parameter values. We experimented with different initial values in parameter optimization and found that the results were not highly sensitive to the initial values provided. Additionally, to account for potential bias in the loss function due to higher cumulative case numbers in later days, we tested two weighted loss functions to better integrate information across the entirety of the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account, models allow each time point to be represented by a probability distribution with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance based on the assumed probability distribution, with the variance possibly being influenced by the mean. However, the lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modellers. One key factor in understanding the variations in model predictions lies in comparing the available data (confirmed cases) with the model's projections. Confirmed cases refer to individuals showing symptoms who sought medical attention, underwent testing, and received a positive COVID-19 diagnosis through DNA or imaging tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms, those in contact with hospitals, individuals with confirmed testing, and those who may be misdiagnosed. Therefore, confirmed cases (data) only represent a portion of the total infected population estimated by the model. An iceberg serves as a fitting analogy for this disparity between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg symbolizes the total infected population, with the visible tip above the water representing the case data, while the submerged portion illustrates the infected individuals who elude public health surveillance and testing—referred to as the hidden epidemic.The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).Why is this problematic for modelers? During model calibration, in order to estimate key parameters such as the transmission rate b by fitting the model output to confirmed cases data, it is necessary to adjust the total number of infectious individuals I(t) in the model prediction by the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different values for the transmission rate b can be estimated through data fitting, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R0, the epidemic scale, and peak time. With the wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b also varies widely, leading to a range of model predictions. This variability in predictions is known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, where different combinations of parameters can produce similar fits to data but divergent epidemic forecasts. Addressing nonidentifiability in model calibration is crucial for the reliability of predictions. Traditional methods, like nonlinear least squares, may struggle with this issue as they rely on basic optimization algorithms that may not effectively handle the complexity of the problem.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a compartment called E is included to represent individuals who have been infected but are not yet infectious. This reflects the realistic biological concept of a latent period in COVID-19 infections, which can last up to 14 days. During this time, newly infected individuals may not yet be able to spread the virus. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, which is the time between infection and becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time between infection and the onset of symptoms like fever and coughing. Unlike SARS, where individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that those with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model, while more biologically realistic than the SIR model, requires additional parameters like the latent period and initial latent population. Despite this, deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are considered negligible in both models. Using newly confirmed case data for calibration, which aligns with the outcomes in both models, the death rate in the R compartment does not affect model fitting. The differential equations for each model are provided, and data calibration is conducted to ensure reliability.

original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. author: enrique
pre_context:
Utilizing a combination of technical, surveillance, and administrative data along with published literature can aid in model calibration, though this can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Alternatively, improving inference methods and model fitting algorithms can help reduce wide confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, which employs Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully narrowed down confidence intervals.

For Nanchang, our baseline predictions consist of prediction intervals generated by sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. Bayesian inference was based on newly confirmed cases in Nanchang from January 21 to February 4, 2020, prior to additional control measures implemented after February 7. These projections provide insight into the potential epidemic in Nanchang without these additional measures. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanchang together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 26, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our analysis, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7th, the peak number of cases would likely reach around 120,000 and the epidemic in Nanchang would not end until mid-May 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.
original_post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. By our projection, without the strict quarantine measures after February 7, the peak case total would reach approximately 120; 000, and the epidemic in Wuhan would not be over before mid-May of 2020.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating realistic network structures (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β is influenced by the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are based on weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen for consistency with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. In a well-mixed population, the default β value is 0.016. Without interventions, the proportions of transmission events in each contact layer are approximately 30% households, 25% workplaces, 15% schools, and 30% community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can modify the value of β. In addition to individual differences in disease severity and time spent in each disease state, individual infectiousness can vary between people and over time, which is modeled using individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Olympia state and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on any given day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted depending on the modeling context, as some studies suggest lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals given default parameter values are shown in Fig 2. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25]. Evidence is mixed as to whether transmissibility is lower if the infectious individual does not have symptoms [55]. We take a default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be modified as needed depending on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
